title: How to Draw a Ferret

steps.headline: Draw a circle for the head.
steps.description: Add guidelines for the facial features.

steps.headline: Add two small circles for the eyes and a small square for the nose.
steps.description: Use an inverted Y for the mouth, curling down from the ferret’s nose (which should be about twice the size of an eye).

steps.headline: Add two small triangles for the ears.
steps.description: Round them at the edges for more anatomical accuracy.

steps.headline: Add a small circle for the upper body and a large oval for the lower body.
steps.description: The upper body should overlap the head almost entirely for now. (The resulting angle will make the ferret look as though it’s turned towards you.)

steps.headline: Add two small ovals for the front legs and three ovals, a large one and two small ones for the back legs.
steps.description: Draw flat ovals for the paws, making sure everything stays connected.

steps.headline: Draw a short tail for the ferret.
steps.description: It should look like what’s shown, falling in a smooth line and curving slightly where it hits the ground.

steps.headline: Outline the image.
steps.description: Draw some fur and whiskers. Erase the guidelines.

steps.headline: Now color it in.
steps.description: This ferret has the same color scheme as a skunk, which is realistic, but don’t be limited by anything.

text: Draw a circle for the head. Add guidelines for the facial features. Add two small circles for the eyes and a small square for the nose. Use an inverted Y for the mouth, curling down from the ferret’s nose (which should be about twice the size of an eye). Add two small triangles for the ears. Round them at the edges for more anatomical accuracy. Add a small circle for the upper body and a large oval for the lower body. The upper body should overlap the head almost entirely for now. (The resulting angle will make the ferret look as though it’s turned towards you.) Add two small ovals for the front legs and three ovals, a large one and two small ones for the back legs. Draw flat ovals for the paws, making sure everything stays connected. Draw a short tail for the ferret. It should look like what’s shown, falling in a smooth line and curving slightly where it hits the ground. Outline the image. Draw some fur and whiskers. Erase the guidelines. Now color it in. This ferret has the same color scheme as a skunk, which is realistic, but don’t be limited by anything.
